title: Basic Pharmacology Test
description: This exam tests basic knowledge of pharmacology concepts

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is classified as a leukotriene receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used to manage asthma and allergic rhinitis.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Ipratropium bromide (A): It is an anticholinergic bronchodilator used in COPD and asthma.
• Diphenhydramine (C): A first-generation H1 antihistamine used for allergies and motion sickness.
• Ranitidine (D): A histamine H2 receptor blocker used for acid reflux and ulcers (withdrawn in many countries).

questions.question: Which of the following beta-blockers has the highest lipid solubility?
questions.explanation:
Propranolol is a highly lipophilic beta-blocker, allowing it to cross the blood-brain barrier and cause CNS effects like sedation.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Esmolol (B): Ultra-short-acting beta-blocker with low lipid solubility, used in acute cardiac conditions.
• Atenolol (C): Hydrophilic beta-blocker with minimal CNS penetration, used in hypertension.
• Pindolol (D): A beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity but lower lipid solubility than propranolol.

questions.question: Which of the following is an adverse effect of serotonin receptor agonists (triptans)?
questions.explanation:
Triptans activate serotonin (5-HT1) receptors, leading to vasoconstriction, which helps in migraine relief.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Hypotension (A): Triptans can cause hypertension, not hypotension.
• Increased appetite (C): Not a known effect; serotonin agonists generally suppress appetite.
• Sedation (D): Unlike first-generation antihistamines, triptans do not cause sedation.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs produces euphoria followed by an intense depressive “crash”?
questions.explanation:
Cocaine blocks dopamine reuptake, causing intense euphoria followed by a severe depressive crash.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Heroin (A): An opioid that induces euphoria but causes respiratory depression instead of a crash.
• LSD (C): A hallucinogen that alters perception rather than causing a "crash." 
• MDMA (D): Causes euphoria but also induces emotional closeness instead of a depressive crash.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is used as a maintenance treatment for opioid dependence?
questions.explanation:
Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in opioid dependence treatment.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Diazepam (A): A benzodiazepine used for anxiety and seizures, not opioid dependence.
• Disulfiram (B): Used for alcohol dependence, not opioid addiction.
• Alprazolam (D): A short-acting benzodiazepine used for anxiety disorders.

questions.question: The mechanism of action of coal tar in psoriasis involves:
questions.explanation:
Coal tar slows down excessive skin cell production in psoriasis.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Inhibition of tyrosinase (A): This is the mechanism of action of skin-lightening agents like hydroquinone.
• Activation of TNF-alpha (C): TNF-alpha is a pro-inflammatory cytokine; coal tar actually reduces inflammation.
• Increasing sebum production (D): Coal tar is not involved in sebaceous gland stimulation.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs should NOT be used for the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)?
questions.explanation:
Aspirin is an NSAID that can worsen GERD by increasing gastric acid secretion and mucosal damage.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Omeprazole (A): A proton pump inhibitor used to reduce stomach acid.
• Ranitidine (B): A former H2 receptor antagonist used for acid reflux (withdrawn in many places).
• Metoclopramide (C): A prokinetic agent that helps in GERD by improving gastric motility.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is a short-acting β2-adrenergic agonist (SABA) used for acute asthma relief?
questions.explanation:
Albuterol is a short-acting β2 agonist (SABA) that provides quick bronchodilation in acute asthma.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Formoterol (A): A long-acting β2 agonist (LABA) used for maintenance therapy.
• Salmeterol (B): Another LABA used in asthma but not for acute relief.
• Tiotropium (D): A long-acting anticholinergic used for COPD rather than asthma.

questions.question: Which NSAID is most potent for postoperative pain relief?
questions.explanation:
Ketorolac is a potent NSAID used for short-term management of moderate to severe pain, often postoperatively.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Aspirin (A): A mild NSAID mostly used for pain and antiplatelet effects.
• Naproxen (B): Longer-acting NSAID used for chronic pain rather than acute postoperative pain.
• Celecoxib (D): A selective COX-2 inhibitor used mainly for arthritis, not severe acute pain.

questions.question: Which drug is a first-generation H1 antihistamine used for motion sickness?
questions.explanation:
Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is effective in motion sickness.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Cetirizine (A): A second-generation antihistamine with minimal sedation, not used for motion sickness.
• Loratadine (C): A non-drowsy antihistamine mainly for allergies, not motion sickness.
• Fexofenadine (D): Another non-sedating antihistamine, not effective for motion sickness.

questions.question: Which cephalosporin is effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa?
questions.explanation:
Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin with strong activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Cefazolin (A): A first-generation cephalosporin with no activity against Pseudomonas.
• Cephalexin (B): Another first-generation cephalosporin used for Gram-positive infections.
• Ceftriaxone (D): A broad-spectrum third-generation cephalosporin but ineffective against Pseudomonas.

questions.question: Which class of β-lactam antibiotics has the broadest spectrum and is resistant to most β-lactamases?
questions.explanation:
Carbapenems (e.g., imipenem, meropenem) have the broadest spectrum and are resistant to most β-lactamases.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Penicillins (A): Less broad spectrum and susceptible to β-lactamases.
• Cephalosporins (B): Broader than penicillins but still susceptible to some β-lactamases.
• Monobactams (D): Effective against Gram-negative bacteria but not as broad as carbapenems.

questions.question: Which fluoroquinolone has activity against Bacteroides fragilis?
questions.explanation:
Moxifloxacin has anaerobic coverage, including Bacteroides fragilis.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Ciprofloxacin (A): Mainly covers Gram-negative aerobes but lacks anaerobic activity.
• Levofloxacin (C): Active against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria but weak against Bacteroides.
• Norfloxacin (D): A narrow-spectrum quinolone used for UTIs.

questions.question: Which antifungal agent is most likely to cause QT interval prolongation, leading to torsades de pointes?
questions.explanation:
Voriconazole is known to prolong the QT interval, increasing the risk of torsades de pointes.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Amphotericin B (A): Causes nephrotoxicity but does not affect QT interval.
• Fluconazole (B): Can cause QT prolongation but less than voriconazole.
• Isavuconazole (D): Shortens QT interval rather than prolonging it.

questions.question: Which drug is a second-line treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB)?
questions.explanation:
Amikacin, an aminoglycoside, is used in MDR-TB when first-line drugs fail.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Rifampin (B): A first-line TB drug.
• Pyrazinamide (C): First-line drug used in combination therapy for TB.
• Isoniazid (D): A primary anti-TB drug, not second-line.

questions.question: Which of the following antimycobacterial drugs can cause red-orange discoloration of body fluids?
questions.explanation:
Rifampin causes red-orange discoloration of urine, sweat, and tears.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Isoniazid (A): Causes hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy but no discoloration.
• Pyrazinamide (C): Can cause hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity but not discoloration.
• Ethambutol (D): Causes optic neuritis but does not affect body fluid color.

questions.question: What is a common adverse effect of somatropin?
questions.explanation:
Somatropin (recombinant GH) can induce insulin resistance, leading to hyperglycemia.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Osteoporosis (A): GH promotes bone growth rather than causing osteoporosis.
• Bradycardia (C): GH does not significantly affect heart rate.
• Hypotension (D): GH does not cause hypotension.

questions.question: Which drug inhibits the enzyme dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4)?
questions.explanation:
Sitagliptin inhibits DPP-4, increasing incretin levels and improving glycemic control.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Acarbose (A): An α-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate digestion.
• Repaglinide (C): A meglitinide that stimulates insulin release.
• Pioglitazone (D): A thiazolidinedione that enhances insulin sensitivity.

questions.question: Which of the following insulins is an intermediate-acting insulin?
questions.explanation:
NPH insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin with a duration of about 12-16 hours.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Insulin detemir (A): Long-acting insulin with a duration of ~24 hours.
• Insulin glulisine (B): A rapid-acting insulin.
• Insulin degludec (D): Ultra-long-acting insulin.

questions.question: Which corticosteroid has the longest duration of action?
questions.explanation:
Dexamethasone has the longest duration of action, lasting 36-72 hours.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Hydrocortisone (A): Short-acting corticosteroid.
• Prednisone (C): Intermediate-acting corticosteroid.
• Methylprednisolone (D): Also intermediate-acting but shorter than dexamethasone.

questions.question: Which class of antihypertensives primarily works by decreasing cardiac output and inhibiting renin release?
questions.explanation:
Beta-blockers reduce cardiac output and suppress renin release from the kidneys, leading to decreased blood pressure.
Why other options are incorrect?
• ACE inhibitors (A): Block angiotensin-converting enzyme to lower blood pressure.
• Calcium channel blockers (C): Reduce vascular resistance by relaxing blood vessels.
• Alpha-blockers (D): Reduce blood pressure by dilating blood vessels but do not significantly affect renin release.

questions.question: Which diuretic has the highest risk of hyperkalemia?
questions.explanation:
Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that inhibits aldosterone, increasing potassium retention.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Furosemide (B): A loop diuretic that causes potassium loss.
• Hydrochlorothiazide (C): A thiazide diuretic that also leads to potassium loss.
• Acetazolamide (D): A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that causes metabolic acidosis but not significant hyperkalemia.

questions.question: Which diuretic is most commonly used for symptomatic relief of congestion in heart failure?
questions.explanation:
Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to relieve pulmonary and peripheral congestion in heart failure.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Acetazolamide (A): Used for glaucoma and altitude sickness.
• Hydrochlorothiazide (C): Less effective for acute congestion.
• Spironolactone (D): Used in heart failure but mainly for long-term aldosterone antagonism.

questions.question: Which drug can be used as an alternative to ACE inhibitors in patients who cannot tolerate them due to a persistent cough?
questions.explanation:
Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that does not cause the bradykinin-related cough associated with ACE inhibitors.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Metoprolol (B): A beta-blocker used for hypertension and heart failure but does not block the renin-angiotensin system.
• Digoxin (C): Used for heart failure and atrial fibrillation but does not replace ACE inhibitors.
• Dobutamine (D): A β1-agonist used in acute heart failure, not for chronic hypertension management.

questions.question: Which drug is most likely to cause QT prolongation?
questions.explanation:
Dofetilide is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug that blocks potassium channels, leading to QT prolongation.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Verapamil (A): A calcium channel blocker that affects conduction but not significantly the QT interval.
• Digoxin (C): Affects cardiac conduction but does not primarily prolong QT.
• Lidocaine (D): A Class IB antiarrhythmic that shortens repolarization rather than prolonging QT.

questions.question: What is a potential life-threatening side effect of Class III antiarrhythmic drugs?
questions.explanation:
Class III antiarrhythmics, like amiodarone and dofetilide, can prolong the QT interval, increasing the risk of torsades de pointes.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Bradycardia (B): A side effect but not the most life-threatening.
• Hypertension (C): Class III drugs do not typically cause significant hypertension.
• Hypoglycemia (D): Not associated with Class III antiarrhythmics.

questions.question: Which of the following is a low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)?
questions.explanation:
Enoxaparin is an LMWH that enhances antithrombin III activity to prevent clot formation.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Rivaroxaban (A): A direct factor Xa inhibitor.
• Warfarin (C): A vitamin K antagonist, not an LMWH.
• Aspirin (D): An antiplatelet agent, not an anticoagulant.

questions.question: Which vitamin is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors inhibited by warfarin?
questions.explanation:
Warfarin inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X).
Why other options are incorrect?
• Vitamin A (A): Important for vision and immune function.
• Vitamin D (B): Regulates calcium metabolism.
• Vitamin C (D): Important for collagen synthesis but not clotting.

questions.question: Which statin has the longest half-life?
questions.explanation:
Atorvastatin has a long half-life (~14 hours) and is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Lovastatin (A): Shorter half-life (~3-4 hours).
• Pravastatin (C): Has a moderate half-life (~1.5-2 hours).
• Simvastatin (D): Shorter half-life (~2-3 hours).

questions.question: What is the therapeutic use of bethanechol?
questions.explanation:
Bethanechol is a muscarinic agonist that stimulates bladder contraction in urinary retention.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Myasthenia gravis (A): Treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like pyridostigmine.
• Parkinson’s disease (C): Treated with dopamine agonists and anticholinergics.
• Hypertension (D): Bethanechol has no role in blood pressure management.

questions.question: What is the primary function of α2-agonists like clonidine?
questions.explanation: Clonidine reduces norepinephrine release, leading to decreased blood pressure.

questions.question: Which drug is combined with levodopa to prevent its peripheral conversion to dopamine?
questions.explanation:
Carbidopa inhibits dopa decarboxylase, preventing peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine, increasing its availability in the CNS.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Entacapone (A): A COMT inhibitor that prevents levodopa breakdown but does not inhibit decarboxylase.
• Bromocriptine (C): A dopamine agonist, not a decarboxylase inhibitor.
• Amantadine (D): Enhances dopamine release but does not affect levodopa metabolism.

questions.question: Which drug can be used as an alternative to interferon-beta in multiple sclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Dimethyl fumarate is an immunomodulator used as an oral alternative to interferon-beta in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Levodopa (B): Used for Parkinson’s disease, not multiple sclerosis.
• Apomorphine (C): A dopamine agonist for Parkinson’s disease.
• Ropinirole (D): A dopamine agonist used for Parkinson’s and restless legs syndrome.

questions.question: Which SSRI has the longest half-life and is therefore associated with the lowest risk of discontinuation syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Fluoxetine has a long half-life (~4-6 days), reducing withdrawal symptoms when discontinued.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Sertraline (A): Moderate half-life (~26 hours), risk of withdrawal symptoms.
• Escitalopram (C): Half-life of ~27-32 hours, shorter than fluoxetine.
• Paroxetine (D): Shortest half-life (~24 hours), highest risk of withdrawal.

questions.question: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics is most associated with akathisia (restlessness)?
questions.explanation:
Risperidone is the atypical antipsychotic most associated with akathisia due to its strong D2 receptor antagonism. Aripiprazole (partial agonist) has a lower risk compared to risperidone but higher than clozapine or olanzapine.
Why Other Options Are Incorrect:
• Clozapine (B): Least likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), including akathisia.
• Olanzapine (C): Lower risk of akathisia compared to risperidone.
• Aripiprazole (D): Partial agonist activity reduces D2 antagonism, leading to lower akathisia risk than risperidone.

questions.question: Which inhalational anesthetic has the lowest minimum alveolar concentration (MAC), making it the most potent?
questions.explanation:
Halothane has the lowest MAC, meaning it is the most potent inhalational anesthetic.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Isoflurane (B): Less potent than halothane.
• Desflurane (C): Rapid onset and offset but higher MAC than halothane.
• Nitrous oxide (D): Highest MAC, meaning the least potent.

questions.question: Which CNS stimulant is a non-stimulant drug approved for ADHD and selectively inhibits norepinephrine reuptake?
questions.explanation:
Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) used for ADHD treatment.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Methylphenidate (A): A stimulant that increases dopamine and norepinephrine.
• Dextroamphetamine (C): A stimulant that enhances dopamine release.
• Modafinil (D): Used for narcolepsy and shift work sleep disorder, not first-line ADHD treatment.

questions.question: Which CNS stimulant is commonly used to improve cognitive function in shift workers?
questions.explanation:
Modafinil is a wakefulness-promoting agent used for shift work sleep disorder and narcolepsy.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Methylphenidate (A): Primarily used for ADHD and narcolepsy, not shift workers.
• Cocaine (C): An illegal stimulant with short-term effects and high abuse potential.
• Atomoxetine (D): Used for ADHD but does not improve cognitive function in shift workers.

questions.question: Which of the following herbs is known as the "sugar destroyer" due to its antidiabetic activity?
questions.explanation:
Gymnema sylvestre contains gymnemic acids that reduce glucose absorption and stimulate insulin release, leading to its nickname "sugar destroyer." 
Why other options are incorrect?
• Momordica charantia (A): Bitter melon, known for its hypoglycemic properties but not the "sugar destroyer." 
• Syzygium jambolana (C): Used for diabetes but works differently by affecting pancreatic β-cells.
• Melia azadirachta (D): Has antimicrobial and blood sugar-lowering properties but is not specifically known as the "sugar destroyer."

questions.question: Which cardiac glycoside-containing plant is used in congestive heart failure treatment?
questions.explanation:
Digitalis lanata contains digoxin, a cardiac glycoside that strengthens myocardial contractions and is used in heart failure.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Punica granatum (B): Pomegranate, known for antioxidant effects, not cardiac glycosides.
• Allium sativum (C): Garlic, used for cholesterol and hypertension but not cardiac glycosides.
• Syzygium jambolana (D): Used for diabetes, not heart failure.

questions.question: Which alkaloid from Atropa belladonna is used to dilate pupils in ophthalmology?
questions.explanation:
Atropine blocks muscarinic receptors, causing pupil dilation (mydriasis) in ophthalmic examinations.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Morphine (B): A narcotic analgesic, not used for pupil dilation.
• Strychnine (C): A neurotoxin causing muscle spasms, not ophthalmic use.
• Thebaine (D): A precursor for opioid synthesis, not used in ophthalmology.

questions.question: Which herbal drug is commonly used to improve libido and sexual performance?
questions.explanation:
Tribulus terrestris is traditionally used to enhance libido and testosterone levels.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Claviceps purpurea (B): Source of ergot alkaloids, used in migraines but not for libido.
• Saraca indica (C): Used in gynecological disorders, not libido enhancement.
• Glycyrrhiza glabra (D): Licorice root, used for ulcers and respiratory issues.

questions.question: Which of the following methods is commonly used for extracting volatile oils?
questions.explanation: Different volatile oils require different extraction techniques, including distillation (e.g., peppermint oil), cold pressing (e.g., citrus oils), and solvent extraction (e.g., delicate flowers).

questions.question: Which volatile oil has been traditionally used to treat bronchitis due to its expectorant properties?
questions.explanation:
Eucalyptus oil contains cineole, which has mucolytic and expectorant properties helpful in bronchitis.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Anise oil (B): Used as an expectorant but less potent than eucalyptus oil.
• Rosemary oil (C): Used for relaxation and memory enhancement, not bronchitis.
• Myristica oil (D): Found in nutmeg, primarily used as a stimulant and carminative.

questions.question: Senna belongs to which class of glycosides?
questions.explanation:
Senna contains anthraquinone glycosides, which have a stimulant laxative effect on the colon.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Isothiocyanate glycosides (A): Found in mustard plants, not in Senna.
• Cyanophore glycosides (B): Found in cyanogenic plants like cassava, releasing cyanide.
• Aldehyde glycosides (D): Found in vanilla, contributing to its aroma.

questions.question: Vanilla contains which type of glycosides?
questions.explanation:
Vanilla contains vanillin, which is an aldehyde glycoside responsible for its flavor and aroma.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Cyanophore glycosides (A): Found in plants releasing hydrogen cyanide.
• Lactone glycosides (B): Found in coumarins and used in anticoagulants.
• Isothiocyanate glycosides (D): Found in mustard and horseradish, causing a pungent taste.

questions.question: Which government is responsible for establishing the Central Pharmacy Council?
questions.explanation: As per Section 3(1)(a), the Federal Government is responsible for establishing the Pharmacy Council of Pakistan, which functions as the Central Council.

questions.question: How often is the Vice-President of the Pharmacy Council elected?
questions.explanation: Section 11(1) states that a Vice-President is elected every year and holds office for one year.

questions.question: Which section defines adulterated drugs?
questions.explanation:
Section 3(a) defines adulterated drugs as drugs that contain filthy, putrid, decomposed substances, or foreign matter such as insects, dirt, or chemicals that make them harmful to health.
Other Related Sections:
• Section 3(f): Defines counterfeit drugs
• Section 3(s): Defines misbranded drugs
• Section 3(zb): Defines spurious drugs

questions.question: Who has the power to fix drug prices?
questions.explanation:
Section 12(1) states that the Federal Government has the power to fix drug prices and regulate the profit percentage of drug manufacturers.
Other Related Sections:
• Section 13: Allows the Federal Government to issue directions to provinces
• Section 14: Covers the establishment of drug testing laboratories

questions.question: Under The Drugs Act, 1976, who is responsible for ensuring that a drug is properly tested for safety before it is sold?
questions.explanation:
Section 14(1) states:
"The Drug Testing Laboratory shall be responsible for conducting tests to determine the safety, efficacy, and quality of drugs before they are made available for sale."

questions.question: What is the role of the Appellate Board under The Drugs Act, 1976?

options.C: To hear appeals against decisions of licensing or registration authorities

questions.answer: (C) To hear appeals against decisions of licensing or registration authorities
questions.explanation: Section 9(1) states that the Appellate Board is responsible for handling appeals against decisions made by the Central Licensing Board, Registration Board, or Licensing Authority.

questions.question: If a manufacturer violates drug labeling regulations under The Drugs Act, 1976, what action can be taken?

options.A: The drug can be immediately banned
options.B: The manufacturer can be fined or imprisoned
options.C: The pharmacist selling the drug will be penalized
options.D: The manufacturer will receive a verbal warning

questions.answer: (B) The manufacturer can be fined or imprisoned
questions.explanation: Section 27(2) states that violating drug labeling laws can result in imprisonment up to 7 years and a fine.

questions.question: Under the Drugs Act of 1976, which section empowers a Drug Inspector to seal a medical store?
questions.explanation: Section 18 of the Drugs Act, 1976, authorizes a Drug Inspector to lock and seal any premises, such as a medical store, if drugs are being manufactured, stored, sold, or exhibited for sale in contravention of the Act's provisions.

questions.question: In which schedule are the standards for establishing drug manufacturing facilities detailed?
questions.explanation: Schedule B outlines the necessary guidelines and standards for setting up drug manufacturing premises, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements.

questions.question: The end product of glycolysis under anaerobic conditions in muscle cells is:
questions.explanation:
Under anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is converted into lactate by lactate dehydrogenase to regenerate NAD⁺ for glycolysis continuation.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Acetyl-CoA (A): Produced under aerobic conditions when pyruvate enters the mitochondria.
• Pyruvate (B): Intermediate product of glycolysis, but it gets converted into lactate in anaerobic conditions.
• Oxaloacetate (D): A key intermediate in the citric acid cycle, not directly related to anaerobic glycolysis.

questions.question: Which enzyme is responsible for DNA replication in eukaryotic cells?
questions.explanation:
DNA polymerase synthesizes new DNA strands during replication by adding nucleotides to the growing strand.
Why other options are incorrect?
• RNA polymerase (B): Involved in transcription, not DNA replication.
• Helicase (C): Unwinds the DNA double helix but does not synthesize new strands.
• Ligase (D): Joins Okazaki fragments in lagging strand synthesis.

questions.question: The optical isomer that rotates plane-polarized light to the right is called:
questions.explanation:
Dextrorotatory compounds rotate plane-polarized light to the right (+).
Why other options are incorrect?
• Levorotatory (B): Rotates light to the left (-).
• Mesomeric (C): Refers to resonance, not optical rotation.
• Racemic (D): Contains equal amounts of dextrorotatory and levorotatory isomers, making it optically inactive.

questions.question: The type of vibration observed in IR spectroscopy includes:
questions.explanation:
In IR spectroscopy, molecular vibrations are classified as stretching (bond length changes) and bending (bond angle changes).
Why other options are incorrect?
• Rotational and translational (B): Observed in microwave and gas-phase spectroscopy.
• Vibrational and translational (C): Translational motions occur in gases but are not IR-specific.
• Spin-spin coupling (D): A concept in NMR spectroscopy, not IR.

questions.question: Which of the following is a major limitation of Flame Photometry?

options.A: Only specific elements can be analyzed

questions.answer: (A) Only specific elements can be analyzed
questions.explanation:
Flame photometry is limited to detecting alkali and alkaline earth metals like Na, K, Ca, and Li.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Requires expensive equipment (B): While some instruments are costly, flame photometry itself is relatively inexpensive.
• Can analyze only non-metallic compounds (C): It primarily analyzes metals, not non-metals.
• Requires vacuum conditions (D): Unlike mass spectrometry, flame photometry does not need a vacuum.

questions.question: Which spectroscopy technique is commonly used for the analysis of drug metabolites in urine?
questions.explanation:
Mass spectrometry is widely used in pharmacokinetics to detect and quantify drug metabolites in biological samples.
Why other options are incorrect?
• UV/Vis Spectroscopy (B): Used for absorbance studies but lacks specificity for metabolites.
• IR Spectroscopy (C): Identifies functional groups but is not highly specific for metabolites.
• Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (D): Used for metal ion analysis, not drug metabolites.

questions.question: Which spectroscopy technique is best suited for real-time reaction monitoring in pharmaceutical manufacturing?
questions.explanation:
IR spectroscopy can monitor chemical changes in real-time by tracking functional group transformations.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (B): Measures metal concentrations, not organic reaction monitoring.
• UV/Vis Spectroscopy (C): Measures absorbance but is not ideal for continuous reaction monitoring.
• Flame Photometry (D): Limited to metal ion analysis.

questions.question: In redox potentiometry, the potential difference is due to:

options.B: Electron transfer between oxidizing and reducing agents

questions.answer: (B) Electron transfer between oxidizing and reducing agents
questions.explanation:
Redox potentiometry measures the potential difference generated by redox reactions involving electron transfer.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Hydrogen ion activity (A): Measured in pH potentiometry, not redox potentiometry.
• Light absorption (C): Basis of UV/Vis spectroscopy.
• Conductivity changes (D): Used in conductometric titrations.

questions.question: Which type of DSC is more commonly used in pharmaceutical analysis?
questions.explanation:
Heat flux DSC is commonly used in pharmaceuticals to analyze melting points, polymorphism, and thermal stability.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Adiabatic DSC (A): Not widely used in routine pharmaceutical analysis.
• Isothermal DSC (B): Used for kinetic studies rather than routine analysis.
• High-pressure DSC (D): Used for specialized high-pressure applications.

questions.question: Which factor improves the resolution of column chromatography?

options.A: Decreasing particle size of stationary phase

questions.explanation: Decreasing particle size, increasing column length, and optimizing flow rate all contribute to improved resolution in chromatography.

questions.question: The stationary phase in GLC must be:
questions.explanation: The stationary phase in gas-liquid chromatography (GLC) is a liquid coated on a solid support and must be non-volatile to remain fixed inside the column.

questions.question: Phase-II drug metabolism reactions are also called?
questions.explanation: Phase-II metabolism involves conjugation reactions such as glucuronidation and sulfation, increasing drug water solubility.

questions.question: Which of the following pharmacokinetic parameters is mostly affected by renal failure?
questions.explanation:
Renal failure significantly reduces drug clearance, leading to drug accumulation and potential toxicity.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Volume of distribution (A): Affected by protein binding and tissue distribution but not primarily by renal failure.
• Half-life (C): Changes as a consequence of reduced clearance but is not the most directly affected.
• Absorption rate (D): Renal failure has minimal impact on drug absorption.

questions.question: The primary site for drug metabolism is:
questions.explanation:
The liver contains enzymes like cytochrome P450, which are responsible for drug metabolism.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Kidney (A): Primarily responsible for drug excretion.
• Intestine (C): Involved in some first-pass metabolism but not the primary site.
• Lungs (D): Some drugs (e.g., inhaled anesthetics) undergo metabolism here, but it is not the main site.

questions.question: Which of the following factors can influence the absorption of weak acids and bases?

options.C: Presence of food in the stomach

questions.explanation: The absorption of weak acids and bases depends on pH, solubility, and food presence, which can alter gastric emptying time and pH.

questions.question: In a two-compartment model, what does the α phase represent?
questions.explanation:
The α phase represents the initial rapid distribution of the drug from the central compartment to peripheral tissues.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Elimination phase (A): Occurs later (β phase).
• Absorption phase (C): Involves drug movement into circulation, not distribution.
• Bioavailability phase (D): Describes the extent of drug absorption, not distribution.

questions.question: Which of the following parameters is NOT typically used to evaluate bioequivalence?
questions.explanation: Bioequivalence is determined by comparing Cmax, AUC, and Tmax, whereas drug stability is related to formulation quality.

questions.question: A lower Tmax indicates:
questions.explanation: A lower Tmax means the drug reaches its peak concentration faster, indicating rapid absorption.

questions.question: The time required for a drug to reach 90% of steady-state concentration without a loading dose is:
questions.explanation: Steady-state concentration is achieved at approximately 3.32 half-lives for 90% accumulation.

questions.question: Using Fried's rule, calculate the dose for an infant aged 6 months if the adult dose is 200 mg.
questions.explanation:
Fried's rule:
  ________________________________________
For a 6-month-old infant: Dose = (Age in months / 150) x Adult Dose = (6/150) x 200 mg = 8 mg.

questions.question: A 1 L IV bag contains 1.5 g of an antibiotic. How much solution (mL) is needed to administer a 375 mg dose?
questions.explanation:
________________________________________
Explanation: 1.5 g is equivalent to 1500 mg in 1000 mL, so the concentration is 1.5 mg/mL. To deliver 375 mg: 375 mg / 1.5 mg/mL = 250 mL.

questions.question: If a prescription calls for 10 mEq of potassium chloride (KCl) and the available stock solution is 2 mEq/mL, how much solution (in mL) should be administered?
questions.explanation:
________________________________________
Explanation: Dose required = 10 mEq. Stock concentration = 2 mEq/mL. Therefore, volume = 10 mEq / 2 mEq/mL = 5 mL.

questions.question: Which drug delivery system bypasses first-pass metabolism?
questions.explanation: IV injections and rectal suppositories (partially) bypass first-pass metabolism, increasing bioavailability.

questions.question: What is the function of glycerin in tinctures?
questions.explanation: Glycerin improves solubility and prevents precipitation, enhancing tincture stability.

questions.question: Which of the following molecules would have the highest boiling point?
questions.explanation: NH₃ has strong hydrogen bonding, leading to a higher boiling point compared to CH₄, O₂, and CO₂.

questions.question: Which of the following phase transitions is exothermic?
questions.explanation: Freezing releases heat (exothermic), while melting, evaporation, and sublimation absorb heat (endothermic).

questions.question: What is the primary function of the sterility test?

options.B: To check for the presence of microorganisms
options.C: To measure the clarity of a solution
options.D: To assess the stability of a formulation

questions.answer: (B) To check for the presence of microorganisms
questions.explanation:
The sterility test is performed to ensure that parenteral and ophthalmic products are free from viable microorganisms.
Why other options are incorrect?
• To determine drug content (A): Drug content is determined using assays, not sterility tests.
• To measure the clarity of a solution (C): Clarity testing is separate and ensures the absence of visible particles.
• To assess the stability of a formulation (D): Stability tests assess degradation over time, not sterility.

questions.question: What is the principle of the clarity test in parenteral preparations?
questions.explanation:
The clarity test ensures that parenteral solutions are free from visible particulate contamination.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Detection of pyrogens (A): Pyrogen testing is done separately to detect fever-inducing substances.
• Identification of microbial contamination (B): This is checked using sterility tests.
• Measurement of drug potency (D): Drug potency is assessed using analytical assays.

questions.question: What is the USP-recommended method for testing large-volume parenterals for sterility?
questions.explanation:
Membrane filtration is preferred for sterility testing of large-volume parenterals because it allows for better recovery of microorganisms.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Direct inoculation (A): Used for small-volume parenterals but not ideal for large-volume samples.
• Pyrogen test (C): Detects fever-producing substances but does not confirm sterility.
• Karl Fischer titration (D): Measures moisture content, not sterility.

questions.question: Which of the following is a major advantage of in vitro bioassays?

options.A: They are more ethical than in vivo assays
options.D: They are more expensive than in vivo tests

questions.answer: (A) They are more ethical than in vivo assays
questions.explanation: In vitro bioassays eliminate the need for live animal testing, making them more ethical and widely accepted in drug screening.

questions.question: What is the standard drying temperature for Loss on Drying in most pharmaceutical samples?
questions.explanation: Loss on Drying (LOD) is typically performed at 105°C to remove moisture content from pharmaceutical samples.

questions.question: According to pharmacopeial standards, what is the acceptable weight variation limit for suppositories weighing less than 1.5g?
questions.explanation: The standard acceptable weight variation for suppositories weighing less than 1.5g is ±10%, as per pharmacopeial regulations.

questions.question: Which excipient is commonly used in chewable tablet formulations to enhance palatability?
questions.explanation: Sucrose is added to chewable tablets to improve taste and increase patient compliance.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a gastro-retentive drug delivery system?
questions.explanation: Floating tablets remain buoyant in the stomach for prolonged drug release, making them an example of a gastro-retentive system.

questions.question: Which organization regulates the quality of pharmaceutical tablets in the United States?
questions.explanation: The USP (United States Pharmacopeia) sets quality standards, while the FDA (Food and Drug Administration) enforces compliance.

questions.question: Which of the following heat transfer mechanisms does not require a medium?

options.D: All of the above require a medium

questions.explanation: Radiation transfers heat through electromagnetic waves and does not require a medium.

questions.question: In fluidized bed drying, the solid particles are:

options.B: Suspended and agitated by a stream of air

questions.answer: (B) Suspended and agitated by a stream of air
questions.explanation: In fluidized bed drying, air lifts the particles, creating a fluid-like motion that enhances drying efficiency.

questions.question: Which size analysis method involves passing particles through a series of sieves with decreasing mesh sizes?
questions.explanation: Sieving uses progressively smaller mesh sizes to separate particles based on size.

questions.question: Which mill utilizes high-velocity air to induce particle-particle collisions for size reduction?
questions.explanation: Fluid Energy Mills use high-velocity air or steam to achieve ultra-fine particle size reduction.

questions.question: Which of the following processes is used in the production of dry powders for inhalation?
questions.explanation:
Spray drying is the standard method for producing dry inhalation powders (e.g., for DPIs).
Why other options are incorrect:
• Lyophilization (A): Used for thermolabile drugs, not typical for inhalers.
• Vaporization (C): Not a pharmaceutical manufacturing process.
• Decantation (D): Separates liquids from solids, irrelevant to powder production.

questions.question: The rate of hydrolysis increases with:
questions.explanation: Higher temperatures accelerate hydrolysis by increasing molecular interactions and reaction rates.

questions.question: Which of the following methods is commonly used for the preparation of suspensions?
questions.explanation: Suspensions can be prepared using trituration, precipitation, or homogenization methods, depending on the formulation requirements.

questions.question: Which method is commonly employed to incorporate solid drug substances into an ointment base?
questions.explanation: Levigation reduces particle size by mixing the drug with a small amount of liquid before incorporating it into the base.

questions.question: Which test is used to detect reducing sugars?
questions.explanation:
Benedict’s test is used to detect reducing sugars (e.g., glucose, fructose) based on their ability to reduce copper(II) sulfate to copper(I) oxide, forming a red precipitate.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Biuret Test (A): Used for detecting proteins, not sugars.
• Salkowski Test (C): Used to detect steroids, not sugars.
• Disintegration Test (D): Determines tablet disintegration time, unrelated to sugar detection.

questions.question: Which test detects aldehydes and reducing sugars?
questions.explanation:
Fehling’s Test detects reducing sugars (aldoses and ketoses) and aldehydes by reducing copper(II) ions to copper(I) oxide, forming a brick-red precipitate.
Why other options are incorrect?
• Tollens’ Test (A): Specific to aldehydes only (does not detect ketoses).
• Molisch’s Test (C): General test for carbohydrates, not specific to reducing sugars.
• Iodine Test (D): Detects starch via a blue-black color, unrelated to reducing sugars or aldehydes.
